content.description: On Buttress # 7. Climb the chimney using all the shelves.
content.location: Buttress 7.

content.description: Start as for Fruition, move over onto the right wall before reaching the corner. Stay about 5 feet right of the Fruition corner.
Climb the face below the prominent tongue,then out to the tip of the tongue. Move left and up to the top.
content.location: At the first buttress on the downstream end.

content.description: The obvious groove in the middle of buttress #8. Follow the groove for ten feet, move left passing an overhang, up into an alcove, exiting left.
content.location: Buttress 8.

content.description: The right side of the large overhang on the downstream side of buttress #6. Start at the left side. Climb broken rock to the second ledge, then attack the overhangs from the center of the ledge. Above the lip follow a short crack to the top.
content.protection: The original piton in the roof was ripped out,and the flake it lived behind on the second ascent attempt. I replaced that piton with a Leeper Z piton at the time, but it is over 20 yrs old and should be tested.
content.location: Buttress 6.

content.description: On the right side of the downstream wall of buttress #6, near the entrance to the arch, climb the short harder looking open book, moving around the outside corner to the right at its top, then up to top.
content.location: Buttress 6.

content.description: Back in the corner, follow a thin finger crack without stepping off left. Climb directly over the flaky overhang to finish.
content.protection: It takes good wires all the way, maybe small cams today, but you have to place every possible piece to stay off the deck.
content.location: Left side of upstream side of buttress three.

content.description: From the back of the V, hand traverse with little protection out the upstream wall to the nose. Clip a pin and move up to the top.
content.protection: Little, but with a 1983 vintage piton.
content.location: Behind the Great Wall there is a V-shaped area formed by the two buttresses. This is on the upstream buttress, on the climber's left.

content.description: This route starts with a crimpy boulder problem right off the deck, protected by small gear.  After reaching the horizontal, plug good gear move slightly right and continue up on decent crimps.  Pass a solid nut placement and run it out to the top!
content.protection: Small to medium gear. Ball nuts or small wires are useful to protect the opening "R" sequence, and then the rest is PG.
content.location: This route is located on the Rotwand wall, and crosses over the original traverse of the Rotwand.

content.description: The right hand side of the leaning pillar to start, then up a crack on the main face.
content.location: On the next formation downstream of Great Wall.

climbs.name: Pro-found
climbs.fa: TR FA: Moffat  lead FA: Musselman and McMillan

content.description: Climb the left face of the pillar at a very thin crack past a small overhang and up to top.
content.protection: RP's and small wires. Protection difficult.
content.location: At the left side of the leaning pillar.

content.description: This wall is broken by a large groove in the center. Climb the groove to the top.
content.location: Downstream wall of buttress five.

content.description: Start at an obvious 4 inch crack and follow to it's end. Move right into the corner and follow to top.
content.location: On the first major buttress.

content.description: Climb the wall a few feet right of the corner,passing an overhang about ten feet off the ground,continue to the top.
content.protection: Difficult pro with some loose rock.
content.location: The left side of the downstream wall of buttress number 5.

content.description: The smaller chimney on the right, within the larger chimney of Would I? Follow chimney to top, passing a constriction.
Similar climbing to the pumper along the left side of the face
content.location: Just left of the pumper along the side of the Great Wall.

content.description:
On the Great Wall, only the center 5.8 route was led, via headpoint.  

  As I understand it this route now sports four bolts.In which case the protection rating would change considerably.
content.location: Center of the Great Wall.

climbs.name: The Great Wall (center - aka the Pumper)

content.description: Slick, Slippery, Polished, Pumpy, Fun!  Classic climbing on smooth red Lockatong Formation argillite interspersed with friable Brunswick Formation shale...
content.location: First Buttress, middle of the face.

content.description:
This is the first route we did at the Edge, and perhaps the most obvious line. Pro is good,sting is in the tail. I think it's the best route here.  

  Climb the steep rock near the center of the wall into an inside corner facing left. Follow the crack over a small overhang to a cedar tree at the top.
content.location: The downstream side of Buttress Two.

content.description: Begin five feet uphill from the lowest point of the wall. Move up following a broken crack to a sloping ledge. Continue following a curving crack moving left through two shallow depressions before reaching the block on the ledge. Continue straight up to the top.
content.protection: Trad pro. It's okay if you get the wires in the scoop.
content.location: Right side of upstream side of buttress three.

content.description: Behind the Great Wall you can scramble up into a vee shaped area formed by the two buttresses. EB takes a line up the center of the downstream wall side.
content.protection: Two partially driven pitons protected the crux on the FA,and were left in place,but may since have disappeared. This horizontal may take small cams now.
content.location: Downstream side of the vee behind the Great Wall.

content.description: From the ledge five feet off the ground on the front of buttress #7, follow two parallel thin cracks up a short overhanging face. Continue up through a steep scoop facing right to the top.
content.location: Buttress 7.

content.description: Climb the face passing to the right of a small evergreen. Continue past horizontal cracks and shelves. Exit just left of the small overhang at the top.
content.location: On the upstream wall of buttress one.

content.description: Climb up the center of the buttress beneath the obvious wide crack, move right into a thin crack, through an overhang about twelve feet off the ground. Go over the overhang at the crack. Continue to the top, finishing directly over the larger overhang there. Be aware that the last overhang, at least in the eighties, had a large block sticking out. When making the moves out and over, pulling on the block it "clunks" down. Bring spare shorts for this.
content.location: On the downhill face of buttress five, facing the stream.

content.description: Follow a thin crack from the left edge of the ledge at the base of Don Genero up the overhanging wall passing a ledge and into an offset overhang, then on to the top.
content.location: Immediately left of Don Genero.

content.description: The Edge is located on private property and is currently CLOSED TO CLIMBING.  The landowner does not tolerate trespassing and climbers have been asked to leave.  If you would like to help resolve access issues here and elsewhere, please consider joining and donating to the  Access Fund. The following info is for historical purposes only:I ( Tom Stryker ) contacted a friend who co-authored an old Stover guide with me, and he did have our Edge notes, and graciously organized and mailed them to me. There are 32 trad routes that were led ground up on gear and a few pins. Mel Hamel, Tom Moffatt and I , had our run of the place, and climbed the lines we could with the gear we had at the time.The original sequence numbers will be a little difficult to use as we always approached from the downstream end (climber's right), but the upstream end (climber's left) is used now.Only four climbs had fixed gear at the time, between 1981 and 1983, two each in the area behind the Great Wall, one pin on Fruition and one on Thunder Road. In some cases small cams which were not available at the time may allow ascents of climbs where the pitons disappeared, but use some care, particularly on the Rotwand, as we were in deck territory every time we went out the the nose to work on getting some gear.As I understand it, some routes have been bolted on the Great Wall. The most common center route on this wall has been led on gear at 5.8 X. We did some other routes that were pretty bold, and I am concerned these would get bolted unknowingly. If you are planning to bolt more routes there I would appreciate any opportunity to fill you in on existing trad routes there.Buttresses and routes, from upstream to downstream.Rotwand* The RotwandGreat Wall* EB, Phone Home* Great Wall Nose* Great Wall (center trad line)* Great Wall right variationLeaning Pillar* Pro-found* Right Hand DriveButtress 8* Strapaducktome * Bondage and DisciplineButtress 7* Don Genero* Would I?* HarelipButtress 6* Three Stooges Go Climbing* Thunder Road* Simple SoloCentral Buttress (Buttress 5)* Monster Mash* Tryin' Times* Stop the Presses* Central Buttress Direct* Knuckle Sandwich* The Nose That RoaredButtress 4 is short and has no routes.Buttress 3* Shattered* FlatteredFruition Buttress (Buttress 2)* Limburger Groove* Self Cleaning* Fruition* TuitionButtress 1* Dead Men Don't Eat Roughage* Mel's Route* The Tongue That Swung
